title: Which one is correct, 'I did know' or 'I knew'? - Quora

response.answer_text: Both “I did know” and “I knew” are correct, but you’ll seldom want to say “I did know.” You would use “I did know” to put exceptionally strong emphasis on “did,” perhaps because you want to underline that you did know in answering someone who falsely claims you didn’t know. He: “You had no idea how much of a problem you were causing.” You: “I did know I was causing a problem, but I had no alternative.” Another reason you might want to stress “did” would be if you wanted to say, “I did know then, but I don’t know now; I’ve just forgotten.” Most of the time - I’d say 95% of the time, plus - you would say “I knew.”

The use of the auxiliary verb, “to do” has two uses. To form questions in using verbs that cannot be made by reversing the indictative word order. e.g. Are you? (to be), Have you? Can you? May I, might we etc . questions indicated by reversing the word order. We do not say “Like you?” but “Do you like?” and similarly for all other verbs. The second use of the auxiliary verb “to do”, is for empahsis. e.g. “I do love you”, “ I did tell the truth” So “I knew” and “I did know” are equivalent in meaning, but one is more emphatic than the other.
